 ABSTRACT This paper first examines the changing size distribution of industry in developing countries by region and over time, and, by reference to firm- level surveys, it discusses the underlying causes. The importance of markets generated by the growth of agriculture and rural incomes for the regional development of industry, both small and large scale, is noted. Second, it discusses the entrepreneurship issue, arguing that while small and large firms alike are highly responsive to the growth of markets, the measured entre- preneurial response is neither as full nor as efficient as is desirable. The third and last part discusses small industry programs and their relation to development policy. Financing and extension programs are considered in detail, and there is a discussion of the risks involved. Some parallels with agricultural credit are discussed, in particular the default problem and the problems associated with concessionary finance. It is also argued that small industries--and, by implication, the programs intended to support them--would stand to benefit from more efficient (and also more labor demanding) policies towards agriculture and industry.  INTRODUCTION The role of small industries in the development process has been the subject of a large number of studies over the past 30 years. The reasons for the interest are familiar, and can be stated briefly. Although large industry has absorbed huge shares of total investment, it still accounts for small shares of industrial employment in all but a few countries now in advanced stages of industrialization. It is also concentrated in metropolitan areas. In contrast, household (or "cottage") industries and small workshops and factories account for appreciably larger shares of recorded industrial employment, are more labor intensive in aggregate, and more widely dispersed in provincial towns and cities. Case histories of medium and larger sized firms have also suggested that much of the growth of employment in large industry is due to the expansion of previously small firms through the size distribution. For these and other reasons it is argued that a shift of investment towards small industry would both improve earnings opportunities for a larger share of the labor force and encourage regional industrial development.l/ In a large measure, these arguments have been accepted, and in most developing countries, governments have introduced special programs of support--for example in the form of small industry finance, extension and advisory services, infrastructure,and programs for the training of managers and workers. It is surprising, given the apparent commitment towards developing small industries, that little is known about how the various programs adopted have worked out in practice. In general terms it can be said that they have often proved to be administratively costly and to have exposed the financial intermediaries involved to significant risks. But beyond this, the information available is not concrete and, in addition, both the designs of the programs and what has been achieved vary greatly. Furthermore, it is clear that the prevailing economic policies of many developing countries stand in direct contradiction to interventions to assist small industries, and necessarily limit what such interventions can be 1/ For recent reviews see World Bank (1978a, 1978b). Of the many earlier studies on the subject the following have become standard: Hoselitz (1959), Staley and Morse (1966), Dhar and Lydall (1960), Berna (1960), and Shinohara (1968) on Japan. See also Kilby (1962) on Nigeria, Aubrey (1951) and United Nations (1969). China's experience with small rural industries has also attracted a lot of attention; see e.g., Sigurdson (1978), Perkins and others (1979) and Riskin (1978). Further references will be cited below.

Administrative controls on interest rates and the borrowings and lendings of the organized financial sector have worked in the same direction by making it profitable for the intermediaries to lend only to large (often foreign-owned) concerns and to a small minority of influential small borrowers of good standing. Even where finance has been made available for small industry, it has again found its way, as in agriculture, mainly to influential borrowers of good standing, attracted by the concessionary rates associated with the programs. Policies towards agriculture, apart from suffering themselves from the huge shift of investment towards large industry, have similarly had adverse effects. By restricting the growth of rural incomes over large regions, they must also have restricted the growth of the markets for the products of mostly small-scale, local industry. It is tempting to argue, therefore, that unless the general structure of economic policies is more appropriate in some first-best sense, there is little that can be accomplished in the way of direct interventions to solve particular problems--such as interventions to improve the supply of skilled labor, infrastructural services and finance to small industry. This would, however, be too extreme a view of the options open. As Landes (1969) remarked, no economic and social system has ever been pushed to its logical limits, and the weight of the evidence is that it is possible for incomes to rise in spite of contradictions in structure. 2/ It is only when the contradictions are overwhelming that we might expect, in the present case, small industry programs to be serving no useful purpose0 But the point remains that it is not possible to assess the effectiveness of small industry programs without first assessing how small industries are affected by the general structure of development policy0 The above considerations lead us to raise three groups of questions: (1) What is the ex post evidence on the effectiveness of small industry' programs? (3) How far would the programs be needed if these policies were better chosen? Would it still be necessary to intervene in the capital markets, for example, if interest rates were allowed to rise to cost- and risk-reflecting levels? Would the risks involved extinguish the institutions interest in the markets, as recent research on uncertainty in economics would suggest? In brief, why intervene? These questions are taken up in Part III. But before this, it is necessary to consider two other issues. The first of these is considered in Part I, and concerns our still- limited understanding of the role of small industries in the industrialization process. It is over 15 years since Staley and Morse reviewed the available information on small industries in developing countries, and made some cross- country comparisons. Several household- and firm-level surveys have appeared since then, and there have been a number of studies (cited below) drawing on more recent census and survey data. Part I attempts to review this material, and to assess what is known about the changing size structure of industry by region and over time. Its aim is purely descriptive. The second issue concerns the efficiency of entrepreneurship in developing countries, and is discussed in Part II. A common theme of the studies reviewed in Part I is that both small and large firms are highly responsive to the opportunities provided by market growth. With respect to small firms, this is especially--though not exclusively--observable in those agricultural regions in which rural incomes are rising, since the dispersion of the product and labor markets and the costs of transport also favor a correspondingly dispersed pattern of production in small-scale activities over a long period. As noted, there is also evidence of some firms expanding through the size distribution. Such changes are apparently taking place notwithstanding the often exceedingly poor backgrounds of the proprietors, and their disadvantages with respect to industrial incentives policies noted above. In these respects, the tacit assumption of many studies on industrial development, that entrepreneurship is in highly elastic supply, is supported. But the additional assumption that entrepreneurship can be ignored in the design of industrial development policies is not supported. In the first place, firm-level studies have pointed to appreciable technical or managerial inefficiencies in small industries, concluding that programs to address these (as with those in agriculture) can be as important as price incentives in raising output. Secondly, practically all available studies of the measured entrepreneurial response are based on biased sampling procedures: they have considered only those members of the labor force who have established successful firms. Examination of the circumstances of those who are not part of this response, or even of those whose firms failed, leads to less complacent assumptions about entrepreneurship.

CHANGES IN THE SIZE STRUCTURE OF INDUSTRY BY REGION AND OVER TIME In the course of industrial growth, the composition of manufacturing activities, when classified according to scale, appears to pass through three phases: (1) A phase in which household manufacturing is predominant, accounting for one-half to three-quarters or more of total manufacturing employment; (2) A phase in which small workshops and factories emerge at a comparatively rapid rate, and act to displace household manufacturing in several sectors; and (3) A phase in which large-scale production becomes predominant, displacing the remaining household manufacturing activities and a large share-- though not the whole--of workshop and small factory production. This phase is partly a product of the second, since the recorded growth of output and employment in large-scale manufacturing can be divided into: (a) the growth of once small firms through the size structure, and (b) the expansion of already large domestic and foreign concerns. This section presents some statistical material on these trends, and discusses the underlying causes. It is apparent that none of the phases are distinct, and in fact there is considerable overlap between the three. Furthermore, the changes differ greatly between sectors, and even between regions within the same country, as it is hoped the following analysis makes clear. However, the classification is useful for making some distinctions that are necessary for thinking about policy. Programs that may be apropriate for one phase because there is a sufficient demand for the services offered (e.g., for fixed-term finance, industrial estates and subcontracting exchanges during phase 2 and afterwards) may be less appropriate earlier because there is not. This is an obvious point, perhaps, but one that is often missed in the design of the programs. The plan below is to examine the trends in aggregate first and then highlight some differences between industries and regions. The above phases are familiar from the historical studies of the now industrialized countries. 1/ Hoselitz used this material in his remarkably prescient article in 1959, to which Livingstone (1980) rightly continues to draw our attention. But it is now possible to say something additional by drawing on the various censuses and studies that appeared in the 1960s and 70s for the developing countries. 1/ See e.g., Parker (1979).

There is little that is not familiar to be said about the predominance and then the gradual decline, over long periods, of household manufacturing. 1/. With the exception of developing countries in advanced stages of the industrialization process, the majority of people recorded as being in this form of employment are in low income, agricultural regions. 2/ It comprises village industries - smiths, shoemakers, garment- makers, handicrafts, masons, carpenters, builders, various crop processing activities and so on - and the subsistence-level, off-farm activities of peasant households. 3/. For the most part, their function is to provide rudimentary inputs and processing services to agriculture and to cater for the non-food needs of the rural population. They seem to differ little from the cottage industries that "persisted in one corner of Europe or another up through the nineteenth century" and which changed slowly or were displaced gradually under the influence of a steady growth of markets. 4/. In the earlier studies of small industries, household manufacturing was commonly dismissed as a tradition bound, low income and economically backward activity, offering few possibilities for raising incomes. For this reason it was sometimes proposed that small industry programs should concentrate on "modern" small industry only, i.e. on workshops and factories above a certain size, say 10 to 20 workers. But later studies questioned this view, and noted in addition that household manufacturing is too important a source of income and employment, over a long period, to be neglected in the design of development policy.  _ 32 Summary To sum up the argument so far, employment in household manufacturing was seen to decline first in relative and then in absolute terms as industrialization proceeds. This observation is neither new nor surprising, but those who have studied the nature and composition of household manufacturing have shown that the aggregate trends conceal the extra-ordinary diversity of these activities and of the changes taking place. Many activities contribute appreciably to incomes and employment, and may expand rapidly in some high growth engineering and consumer goods industries. In these respcts, as King noted 1/ "recent research has been correct to note the side effect of informal activity upon raising the standard of living of peasant (and presumably urban) families." As regards small workshops and factories, the available evidence suggests that they emerge rapidly in response to the growth of markets - at least in periods before industrialization is in an advanced phase. Although more evidence and analysis is required to improve our understanding of the factors involved, the markets generated by agricultural growth, in regions where the labor force is predominantly rural, is probably the main explanation, together with the conditions of infrastructure and transport in those regions. This implies, of course, that the nature of the agricultural development strategy is exceedingly important in determining both the size and the regional distributions of industrial development; further material on this theme is disccused in Part III. While large scale industry eventually predominates as indus- trialization proceeds, much of its growth appears to be rooted in the expansion of once small firms through the size distribution. The evidence on this, however, is not as forthcoming as one would wish; there is still much to be ascertained, for instance, about the extent of ownership of manufacturing establishments by already large domestic and foreign corporations. That the contribution of the growth of small firms to the development of large industry becomes appreciable, however, as industrialization proceeds, is not disputed by those who have studied the origins of firms. If this conclusion is correct, it is all the more remarkable given the exceedingly unequal ways in which industrialization and financial policies have favored large-scale in most developing countries; the material on this subject is also considered in Part III. 1/ Op. cit., p. 28.

Over long periods of the industrialization process, employment in household manufacturing, and in small workshops and factories, far outweighs that that is (or that could be) provided by large industry, notwithstanding the huge concentration of investment and of supporting services on the latter over the past twenty to thirty years. Part I reviewed the main reasons for this and outlined the changes taking place. Since a short summing up was provided at the end, no further comments are necessary here. The conclusions to the analysis on entrepreneurship, in Part II, have also been summed up previously. Suffice it to recall that while the entrepreneurial response to market growth is highly elastic, according to the available evidence, the managerial or "X" inefficiencies associated with the response are appreciable, and most of those who have studied the subject have supported the idea of training and advisory programs to address the problem. In fact, many countries have such programs. Turning to programs of support for small industries,several issues arise. The most general one, as noted variously above,concerns the shortage of ex post evaluations of the many programs that have been undertaken in developing countries. Even particular aspects of these programs, such as the provision of training and advisory services, vary greatly in approach between one country and another, and it is obvious that there would be much to be learned from a comparison of the experiences of different countries. In Part III, an attempt was made to examine finance and extension, based on project work in several countries. Large gaps in our knowledge remain, however, e.g. with respect to infrastructure and management and worker- training programs, to mention three. With respect to small industry finance, several parallels with the findings of those who have studied agricultural credit were noted. Principally, the much discussed risks of the owners of small industries defaulting on loans are often proving to be real. In fact, the default rates are high enough in some programs to raise the most fundamental questions about the economic desirability of the continuance of those programs as they are presently designed. Consessionary finance, for example, has been the general rule, attracting - and for the most part going to - influential borrowers of good standing. Since these borrowers are, in theory, low risk, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that concessionary finance, with its attendant administrative controls, invites loose banking practices and aggravates the risks. Hence the commonplace argument for cost and risk-reflecting interest rates.
 _ 64 - While higher interest rates than now prevail would be desirable, however, we have argued that this alone would not secure an efficient flow of institutional finance to potentially low-risk borrowers currently denied access to it. There are several reasons for this, which at the risk of repetition we might state once more: - (i) Risk reflecting interest rates would be far higher than is commonly supposed until the financial instituions are fully adapted to the task of lending to large numbers of small borrowers. Even if they were politically tolerable, which is unlikely to be the case, they would probably extinguish or greatly reduce the market. (ii) They would also impose an appreciable external cost on potentially low risk borrowers with sound and efficient projects. (iii) An efficiently functioning financial system requires the development of an accounting base among the borrowers, both small and large,legally acceptable documentaion of assets held, legally developed procedures for handling foreclosures and maintaining repayment discipline, and developed insurance markets. In each of these respects, the deficiencies that exist in developing countries are conspicuous, and require a number of measures in addition to a proper management of interest rate policies. (iv) While there is evidence that the risks decline if and as information and experience are accumulated within the institutions, this takes place over periods that are not short,on account of (iii) among other reaons. Thus assessments of the profitability of lending to small industry require long time horizons, increasing the uncertainties further, and leading to differing perspectives between the public and private sectors as to the desirability of starting a lending program. (v) There are reasons for believing that, when risks arise appreciably, the objective functions of the financial institutions are different from that dictated by the
 _ 65 - interests of economic efficiency; specifically, there is evidence of risk- avoidance. As long as these problems remain significant the conclusion is unavoidable that a transformation of the financial institutions policies will nof take place - except over an exceedingly long period - without risk- guarantee programs and the involvement of the public banks. It is nevertheless clear that the financing programs would function better if they were accompanied by a relaxation of administrative controls on interest rate policies and the borrowings and lendings of financial intermediaries. Under these circumstances the interest rates would rise to levels that would roughly reflect the costs of raising resources and lending to low-risk borrowers. This argument is not new. But it is strengthened, it is hoped, by the evidence presented in the text and by reference to recent research on uncertainty in economics. The small industry programs themselves are also accompanied by administrative controls in many countries, e.g. in terms of the types of firms and assets to be financed. Ostensibly, they were intended to encourage the intermediaries only to finance "job creating" projects, and have led to, among other things, the much discussed neglect of working capital finance and to the exclusion of firms seeking to raise output without necessarily expanding employment. Again, we have argued that such controls both increase the risks of the programs and reduce their capacity to improve employment opportunties. For more detail, the reader must be referred back to the discussion of the employment issue in Part III. It is sometimes argued that if leading sector policies were more appropriately chosen, direct interventions to assist small industries would not be necessary. Under leading sector policies are included tariffs, investment incentives and policies towards agriculture. As we argued in Part III, however, this is a fundamentally wrong way of interpreting the purposes of small industry programs. Properly considered, these programs are not intended to be an alternative, but instead to address specific sources of market failure (e.g. in the capital markets) and of inefficiency (e.g. management or X inefficiency) that would limit the effectiveness of a movement towards more desirable leading sector policies. Equally, it is true that small industries would stand to gain from the long-standing proposals for a reform of these policies -in particular from a more labor demanding structure of industrial incentives and tariffs, and from a more broadly-based growth of agiculture. For this reason it was concluded that the more efficient (and also the more labor demanding) the leading sector policies, the more efficient the small industry programs are likely to be. This conclusion is, I believe, generally applicable.

doc.abstracts: This paper first examines the changing size distribution of industry in developing countries by region and over time, and, by reference to firm-level surveys, it discusses the underlying causes. The importance of markets generated by the growth of agriculture and rural incomes for the regional development of industry, both small- and large-scale, is noted. Second, it discusses the entrepreneurship issue, arguing that while small and large firms alike are highly responsive to the growth of markets, the measured entrepreneurial response is neither as full nor as efficient as is desirable. The third and last part discusses small industry programs and their relation to development policy. Financing and extension programs are considered in detail, and there is a discussion of the risks involved. Some parallels with agricultural credit are discussed. It is also argued that small industries would stand to benefit from more efficient policies towards agriculture and industry.
